articles.headline: Getting Tesla From Here to There
articles.snippet: Tesla Motors gets raves for its Model S, and Wall Street loves the company’s soaring stock. But it remains to be seen whether Tesla can actually sell the cars.
articles.abstract: Tesla Motors gets raves for its Model S, and Wall Street loves the company’s soaring stock. But it remains to be seen whether Tesla can actually sell the cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether Tesla Motors can meet its ambitious growth targets — not to mention support its high-flying stock price — may well depend on people like Jason Berkley.

articles.headline: Pressure Rises on Hamas as Patrons’ Support Fades
articles.snippet: The Muslim Brotherhood’s sudden ouster in Egypt by the new military-backed government has ruptured a crucial economic and diplomatic lifeline for Gaza’s militant rulers.
articles.abstract: The Muslim Brotherhood’s sudden ouster in Egypt by the new military-backed government has ruptured a crucial economic and diplomatic lifeline for Gaza’s militant rulers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — The tumult roiling the Arab world had already severed the lifeline between the Palestinian militant group Hamas and two of its most important patrons, Iran and Syria.

articles.headline: New Rules Would Cut Silica Dust Exposure
articles.snippet: The proposal to limit crystalline silica, which causes the irreversible respiratory disease silicosis, would strengthen exposure limits adopted four decades ago.
articles.abstract: The proposal to limit crystalline silica, which causes the irreversible respiratory disease silicosis, would strengthen exposure limits adopted four decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed long-awaited rules on Friday to limit crystalline silica, a move it said would prevent nearly 700 deaths a year by reducing exposure to these very small particles that can cause lung cancer and other diseases.

articles.headline: A Blunt Chief Justice Unafraid to Upset Brazil’s Status Quo
articles.snippet: Joaquim Barbosa is the driving force behind a series of establishment-shaking rulings, turning Brazil’s highest court — and him in particular — into a newfound political power.
articles.abstract: Joaquim Barbosa is the driving force behind a series of establishment-shaking rulings, turning Brazil’s highest court — and him in particular — into a newfound political power.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Brazil’s highest court has long viewed itself as a bastion of manners and formality. Justices call one another “Your Excellency,” dress in billowing robes and wrap each utterance in grandiloquence, as if little had changed from the era when marquises and dukes held sway from their vast plantations.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Win Ruling in Argentina Bond Case
articles.snippet: Hedge funds won the appeals court ruling, but may not receive a big financial return.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds won the appeals court ruling, but may not receive a big financial return.
articles.lead_paragraph: A dogged group of hedge funds secured a significant victory in a federal appeals court on Friday in a case that is likely to have far-reaching effects on international bond markets, parts of the banking system and the struggling nation of Argentina.

articles.headline: In Paper War, Flood of Liens Is the Weapon
articles.snippet: Members of the anti-government “sovereign citizen” movement are increasingly using fraudulent lien filings to retaliate against local officials by overwhelming them with paperwork.
articles.abstract: Members of the anti-government “sovereign citizen” movement are increasingly using fraudulent lien filings to retaliate against local officials by overwhelming them with paperwork.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — One of the first inklings Sheriff Richard Stanek had that something was wrong came with a call from the mortgage company handling his refinancing.

articles.headline: After Mishaps, Nasdaq Loses Standing to Rivals
articles.snippet: The reputation of the market operator has suffered from recent technical problems and poor communication with other members of the industry.
articles.abstract: The reputation of the market operator has suffered from recent technical problems and poor communication with other members of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq was once the upstart of the financial world, set to take over the American stock market. Now, the company is looking more like a vulnerable also-ran.

articles.headline: Questions for Microsoft as It Nears a Crossroad
articles.snippet: Few obvious candidates to replace Steven A. Ballmer as chief have emerged, but his succession was never going to follow the typical business playbook.
articles.abstract: Few obvious candidates to replace Steven A. Ballmer as chief have emerged, but his succession was never going to follow the typical business playbook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s plan, announced Friday, to replace Steven A. Ballmer as its chief executive does not exactly follow — at least to people outside the company — the way they draft these things in business school.

articles.headline: New Jobs! If Only It Were True
articles.snippet: The United States Department of Agriculture often trumpets the numbers of jobs that are expected to result from loans. Whether these jobs are actually created is another question.
articles.abstract: The United States Department of Agriculture often trumpets the numbers of jobs that are expected to result from loans. Whether these jobs are actually created is another question.
articles.lead_paragraph: CREATING jobs is an essential goal today, given our high unemployment rate. But when job programs rely on taxpayer backing, their success or failure should be clearly disclosed.

articles.headline: Needed at Microsoft: A Catch-Up Artist
articles.snippet: For Steve Ballmer’s eventual successor, the challenges are many. Some of the same factors that helped Microsoft in the PC market are working against it as it tries to catch Google and Apple.
articles.abstract: For Steve Ballmer’s eventual successor, the challenges are many. Some of the same factors that helped Microsoft in the PC market are working against it as it tries to catch Google and Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO months ago, Bill Gates met with members of the New York Times editorial board and a few editors and reporters. Public health was on his mind, and he spoke eloquently about the progress being made to combat diseases like tuberculosis and malaria, and the work of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

articles.headline: Egypt Widens Crackdown and Meaning of ‘Islamist’
articles.snippet: Political abuses and politicized prosecutions are hardly new in Egypt, but since the military takeover last month, some rights activists say the authorities are acting with a sense of impunity.
articles.abstract: Political abuses and politicized prosecutions are hardly new in Egypt, but since the military takeover last month, some rights activists say the authorities are acting with a sense of impunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Having crushed the Muslim Brotherhood, the Egyptian authorities have begun cracking down on other dissenters, sometimes labeling even liberal activists or labor organizers as dangerous Islamists.

articles.headline: Platinum Card and Text Alert, via Pawnshop
articles.snippet: As banks zero in on more affluent customers and close branches in poor areas, pawnshops are stepping into the void to offer an array of services.
articles.abstract: As banks zero in on more affluent customers and close branches in poor areas, pawnshops are stepping into the void to offer an array of services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Linda Ballard, 61, uses the word “love” to describe her banking relationship, lauding the ease of cashing her bimonthly paycheck, the convenience of text alerts about her balance and the features on the platinum card that she was upgraded to in July.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Court Is ‘One of Most Activist,’ Ginsburg Says, Vowing to Stay
articles.snippet: Amid calls from some liberals that she step down in time for President Obama to name her successor, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said she was fully engaged in work.
articles.abstract: Amid calls from some liberals that she step down in time for President Obama to name her successor, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said she was fully engaged in work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 80, vowed in an interview to stay on the Supreme Court as long as her health and intellect remained strong, saying she was fully engaged in her work as the leader of the liberal opposition on what she called “one of the most activist courts in history.”

articles.headline: Confident Syria Used Chemicals, U.S. Mulls Action
articles.snippet: An Obama aide’s statement that Syria’s promise to allow United Nations inspectors access to the site of a possible chemical attack was “too late” appeared to move the United States closer to potential military action.
articles.abstract: An Obama aide’s statement that Syria’s promise to allow United Nations inspectors access to the site of a possible chemical attack was “too late” appeared to move the United States closer to potential military action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Moving a step closer to possible American military action in Syria, a senior Obama administration official said Sunday that there was “very little doubt” that President Bashar al-Assad’s military forces had used chemical weapons against civilians last week and that a Syrian promise to allow United Nations inspectors access to the site was “too late to be credible.”
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Olbermann Set to Return to ESPN and Sports News
articles.snippet: Sixteen years after an acrimonious parting, Keith Olbermann and the network are putting on happy faces for their reunion Monday on “Olbermann” on ESPN2.
articles.abstract: Sixteen years after an acrimonious parting, Keith Olbermann and the network are putting on happy faces for their reunion Monday on “Olbermann” on ESPN2.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sixteen years after an acrimonious parting, Keith Olbermann and ESPN are putting on happy faces for their highly anticipated reunion, the premiere on Monday of “Olbermann” on ESPN2, the spinoff channel that Mr. Olbermann helped start, falteringly, in 1993. This time, both sides say, no faltering.

articles.headline: A Calculated Push Into Entertainment Lifts ‘Duck Dynasty’ Family’s Fortunes
articles.snippet: Willie Robertson and his family made a conscious dive into the entertainment world, lifting a regional business based on duck hunting into an international phenomenon.
articles.abstract: Willie Robertson and his family made a conscious dive into the entertainment world, lifting a regional business based on duck hunting into an international phenomenon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget the ZZ Top beards and the Bayou accents, the Robertsons of West Monroe, La., are a family of traditional American entrepreneurs: ambitious, rich and spectacularly successful.

articles.headline: Young Tech Sees Itself in Microsoft’s Ballmer
articles.snippet: Those in mobile and cloud computing, which Microsoft has not taken full advantage of, know that they could one day face similar problems.
articles.abstract: Those in mobile and cloud computing, which Microsoft has not taken full advantage of, know that they could one day face similar problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As a young executive at Microsoft, Steven A. Ballmer helped topple older, slower-moving technology giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation, Wang and Novell.

articles.headline: War on Leaks Is Pitting Journalist vs. Journalist
articles.snippet: The recent security and military leaks have received predictable criticism from the government, but a number of journalists have also lashed out at those who are closest to the stories.
articles.abstract: The recent security and military leaks have received predictable criticism from the government, but a number of journalists have also lashed out at those who are closest to the stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: A disgruntled loner with access to military secrets comes across documents that pull back the veil on government actions in a lost war and decides for a variety of reasons, some noble and some personal, to share them with the world.

articles.headline: Amgen Buys Producer of Drugs for Cancer
articles.snippet: Amgen has huge sales of drugs that help patients cope with chemotherapy and counter some of the effects of cancer, but it has long wanted drugs that directly attack the tumors themselves. In buying Onyx, it acquires some.
articles.abstract: Amgen has huge sales of drugs that help patients cope with chemotherapy and counter some of the effects of cancer, but it has long wanted drugs that directly attack the tumors themselves. In buying Onyx, it acquires some.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although Amgen is the world’s biggest biotechnology company, the drug maker has been mostly absent from one of the industry’s biggest and fastest-growing markets: cancer drugs.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Egypt Military Enlists Religion to Quell Ranks
articles.snippet: Egyptian military leaders are worried about insubordination among the rank and file after members of the security forces killed hundreds of their fellow countrymen.
articles.abstract: Egyptian military leaders are worried about insubordination among the rank and file after members of the security forces killed hundreds of their fellow countrymen.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian military has enlisted Muslim scholars in a propaganda campaign to persuade soldiers and policemen that they have a religious duty to obey orders to use deadly force against supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: Shoeshines Keep Wall Street in the Black (or Maybe Brown)
articles.snippet: In-house shoeshine service has proved resilient, surviving the rise of technology and even the 2008 financial crisis, which snuffed out many of Wall Street’s quirks.
articles.abstract: In-house shoeshine service has proved resilient, surviving the rise of technology and even the 2008 financial crisis, which snuffed out many of Wall Street’s quirks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mauricio Dias was being courted by Wall Street.

articles.headline: Kerry Cites Clear Evidence of Chemical Weapon Use in Syria
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the use of chemical weapons in attacks on civilians in Syria last week was undeniable and that the Obama administration would hold the Syrian government accountable.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the use of chemical weapons in attacks on civilians in Syria last week was undeniable and that the Obama administration would hold the Syrian government accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the use of chemical weapons in attacks on civilians in Syria last week was undeniable and that the Obama administration would hold the Syrian government accountable for a “moral obscenity” that has shocked the world’s conscience.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: BATS and Direct Edge to Merge, Taking On Older Rivals
articles.snippet: Combining BATS Global Markets and Direct Edge will vault the new company past Nasdaq to become the second-largest exchange operator in the United States, as the industry continues to face pressure to consolidate.
articles.abstract: Combining BATS Global Markets and Direct Edge will vault the new company past Nasdaq to become the second-largest exchange operator in the United States, as the industry continues to face pressure to consolidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, William O’Brien, the chief executive of the trading platform Direct Edge, and several of his senior managers flew discreetly to Kansas City, Mo. Waiting for them at the Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport there were Joe Ratterman, head of the rival BATS Global Markets, and his team.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: In Obama’s High-Level Appointments, the Scales Still Tip Toward Men
articles.snippet: President Obama, who is considering candidates for a new Federal Reserve leader, has named no more women to major posts than Bill Clinton did. Janet L. Yellen, the Fed’s vice chairwoman, is a finalist.
articles.abstract: President Obama, who is considering candidates for a new Federal Reserve leader, has named no more women to major posts than Bill Clinton did. Janet L. Yellen, the Fed’s vice chairwoman, is a finalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Behind the roiling conversation over whether President Obama might make Janet L. Yellen the first female leader of the Federal Reserve is an uncomfortable reality for the White House: the administration has named no more women to high-level executive branch posts than the Clinton administration did almost two decades ago.
